greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Additive function a(n) defined by the recursive formula a(1)=1 and a(p^k)=a(k) for any prime p.
comment: That is, if i, j, k, ... are relatively prime, then a(i*j*k*...) = a(i)+a(j)+a(k)+... - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 20 2007

Starts almost the same as A001221 (the number of distinct primes dividing n): the first twelve terms which are different are a(1), a(64), a(192), a(320), a(448), a(576), a(704), a(729), a(832), a(960), a(1024) and a(1088), since the first non-unitary values of n are a(6) and(10). - _Henry Bottomley_, Sep 23 2002
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
formula: a(1) = 1, a(n) = sum(k=1..A001221(n), a(A124010(n,k)) ) for n > 1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 27 2011
mathematica: a[1] = 1; a[n_] := a[n] = Plus @@ a /@ FactorInteger[n][[All, 2]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 105}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Sep 19 2012 *)
results.author: _Steven Finch_, Sep 26 2001
